tn.text: This word is used to mark a new part of the story.

tn.ref: Go from your country, and from your relatives
tn.text: "Go from your land, from your family"

tn.ref: I will make of you a great nation
tn.text: Here "you" is singular and refers to Abram, but Abram represents his descendants. AT: "I will start a great nation through you" or "I will make your descendants become a great nation" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
The word "name" represents the person's reputation. AT: "and make you famous" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The words "to other people" are understood. AT: "you will be a blessing to other people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: whoever dishonors you I will curse
tn.text: "I will curse whoever treats you in a shameful way" or "if anyone treats you as worthless, I will curse him"

tn.ref: Through you will all the families of the earth be blessed
tn.text: This can be made active. AT: "I will bless all the families of the earth through you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"Because of you" or "Because I have blessed you"
This includes animals and non-living property.

tn.ref: the people that they had acquired
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "slaves that they had accumulated" (UDB) or 2) "the people whom they had gathered to be with them."

Only Abram's name is mentioned because he was the head of the family. God had given him the command to take his family and go there. AT: "So Abram and his family went through the land" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"the land of Canaan"
Moreh was probably the name of a place. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: Yahweh, who had appeared to him
tn.text: "Yahweh, because he had appeared to him"
Abram had many people with him as he traveled. People who moved from place to place lived in tents. AT: "they set up their tents"

tn.ref: called on the name of Yahweh
tn.text: "prayed in the name of Yahweh" or "worshiped Yahweh"
"Then Abram took his tent and continued journeying." (See [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"toward the Negev region" or "toward the south" or "south to the Negev desert" (UDB)
The crops did not grow well that season. This can be made explicit. AT: "There was a shortage of food" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"in the area" or "in the land where Abram was living"
Possible meanings are 1) "went further south" (UDB) or 2) "went away from Canaan into." It would be best to translate this using your usual words for going from a higher place to a lower place.

tn.ref: they will kill me ... you alive
tn.text: The reason they would kill Abram can be made explicit: "they will kill me so that they can marry you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: so that my life will be spared because of you
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "so that, because of you, they will not kill me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

Possible meanings are 1) This phrase is used here to mark where the action starts, and if your language has a way for doing this, you could consider using it here, or 2) "And that was what happened" (UDB).

tn.ref: The princes of Pharaoh saw her
tn.text: "Pharaoh's officials saw Sarai" or "the king's officials saw her" (UDB)

tn.ref: the woman was taken into Pharaoh's household
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "Pharaoh took her into his household" or "Pharaoh had his soldiers take her into his household" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Sarai

Possible meanings are 1) "Pharoah's family," that is, as a wife, or 2) "Pharaoah's house" or "Pharaoh's palace," a euphemism for Pharaoh making her one of his wives. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
"for Sarai's sake" or "because of her"
This can be made more explicit. AT: "because Pharaoh intended to take Sarai, Abram's wife, to be his own wife" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"Pharaoh called Abram" or "Pharaoh ordered Abram to come to him"

tn.ref: What is this that you have done to me?
tn.text: Pharaoh used this rhetorical question to show how angry he was about what Abram had done to him. It can also be stated as an exclamation. AT: "You have done a terrible thing to me!" (UDB). (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Then Pharaoh gave orders to his men concerning him
tn.text: "Then Pharaoh directed his officials concerning Abram"

tn.ref: and they sent him away, along with his wife and all that he had
tn.text: "and the officials sent Abram away from Pharoah, with his wife and all his possessions"
